title: Where does Marcus Jones rank among the best two-way players in Patriots history?
author: Colin McCarthy
bullets: Marcus Jones ranks as the third-best two-way player in New England Patriots history, excelling in both defensive and return roles.
Jones has six touchdowns over four seasons, including three return, two defensive, and one receiving touchdown since 2022.
Mike Vrabel tops the list, notable for 10 receiving touchdowns as a defensive player, including Super Bowl scores.

title: These are the best Cape Cod chips, according to readers
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Nearly 1,000 Boston.com readers voted on their favorite Cape Cod chip flavors amid the Hyannis facility closure news.
The Original flavor was the top pick, followed by Dark Russet and Sea Salt & Vinegar in reader rankings.
The Hyannis facility closure ends Cape Cod chips' local ties, but production and flavors will continue elsewhere.

title: High-end supermarket opening first Mass. location, alongside drive-thru coffee shop’s second
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Sprouts Farmers Market and 7 Brew Coffee granted approvals to replace vacant Honda dealership in Weymouth.
The new Sprouts location in Weymouth will be the first in New England; 7 Brew's second Massachusetts site.
Developers plan to start construction in spring on the 90,000-square-foot site at Front, Main, and Winter streets.

title: Sick of winter? Here’s what spring will look like in New England, per the Old Farmer’s Almanac
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: The Old Farmer’s Almanac predicts warmer-than-average temperatures and drier conditions for New England this spring.
Average temperatures in May may be 3°F above normal in the Northeast, including NH, VT, ME, and western MA.
Precipitation is expected to be below average from April to May, with no significant snowfall predicted.

title: Tony Dungy refuses to share if he voted for Belichick, Kraft on Hall-of-Fame ballot
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Tony Dungy, a Hall of Fame voter, declined to reveal his choices regarding Bill Belichick and Robert Kraft.
Belichick and Kraft were not elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame's Class of 2026.
The Hall of Fame Class of 2026 will be announced at the NFL Honors event in San Francisco on Thursday.

title: ‘You changed my life’: Cory Durden’s Cinderella season continues with Patriots
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Cory Durden emerged as a key player for the Patriots after being signed as a practice-squad member in August 2025.
Durden played all 17 regular-season games, logging 474 snaps, and earned a 72.8 PFF grade, ranking 20th among 134 defensive linemen.
Durden has provided critical postseason contributions, including two QB hits and 13 pressures, influencing the AFC Championship game outcome.

title: Payton Pritchard thrives in return to bench as Celtics roll over Mavericks: 6 takeaways
author: Tom Westerholm
bullets: Celtics beat Mavericks 110-100, bringing their record to 32-18 with Jaylen Brown scoring 33 points and grabbing 11 rebounds.
Payton Pritchard scored 26 points off the bench after being replaced in the starting lineup by Baylor Scheierman.
Cooper Flagg excels for Mavericks with 36 points, nine rebounds, and six assists against his childhood team, the Celtics.

title: Recent homes sales in Greater Boston (Feb. 4)
author: The Boston Globe
bullets: Abington home sales include a one-family Cape Cod for $720,000 and a ranch for $560,000.
In Allston, a 1920-built condo decker on Chester Street sold for $590,000.
Boston's most expensive recent sale was a Dalton Street condo for $9,500,000.

title: Manhole fires on Newbury Street prompt building and street evacuations
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Six manholes exploded on Newbury Street in Boston, prompting evacuations from Gloucester Street to Dartmouth Street.
Streets closed included Newbury Street between Exeter and Clarendon Streets and Dartmouth Street between Boylston and Commonwealth Avenue.
No injuries were reported; the explosions were linked to an electrical issue according to fire officials and WCVB.

title: South Station’s new fare gates still out of service more than a week after snow storm
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: South Station's new fare gates have been out of service since January 25-26 due to a major snowstorm.
The MBTA shut down and wrapped the gates to protect them from 16-23 inches of snow and cold temperatures.
Installed in December for $3.3 million, the gates require ticket scans and remain closed as assessments continue.
